File.Title: Retrograde Labeling of Neurons in the Spinal Cord That Project Directly to the Amygdala or the Orbital Cortex in the Rat

Abstract.S: The amygdala and orbital cortex are thought to play an important role in the regulation of autonomic functions, hormonal secretion, and behavioral expression in response to sensory stimulation.
The responsiveness of neurons in these regions to stimulation of cutaneous and visceral organs indicates that sensory information reaches the amygdala and orbital cortex.
In the past, a large number of studies have thoroughly documented multiple neural pathways by which sensory information can reach these regions via relay nuclei in the brainstem and diencephalon.
Recent studies reported that the amygdala and orbital cortex also receive direct input from the spinal cord.
The aim of this study was to determine the magnitude and the origin of these projections in the rat.
Injections of the retrograde tracer Fluoro-Gold (FG), restricted to the amygdala, labeled several hundred neurons bilaterally (60% contralateral) throughout the length of the spinal cord.
More than 60% of labeled neurons were found in the lateral reticulated area of the deep dorsal horn and the gray matter surrounding the central canal.
Many neurons were also found in the lateral spinal nucleus.
Labeled neurons were concentrated in upper lumbar and upper cervical segments.
Injections of Fluoro-Gold that were centered in the orbital cortex labeled only a small number of neurons (73% contralateral) within the spinal cord.
Most labeled neurons were found in the lateral reticulated area.
Neurons located in the intermediate zone and the gray matter surrounding the central canal were found mainly in upper lumbar and upper cervical segments.

Introduction.S: The amygdala (Ben-Ari, '81; Kapp et al., '81; Ursin et al., '81) and the orbital cortex (Sterb and Smith, '55; Holson, '86; Sullivan and Henke, '86) are components of the limbic system that have been associated with autonomic, neuroendocrine, and emotional regulation.

For both the amygdala (MacLean and Delgado, '53; Chapman et al., '54; Anand and Dua, '56; Hilton and Zbrozyna, '63; Reis and Oliphant, '64; Bonvallet and Gary Bobo, '72; Kaada, '72; Mogenson and Calaresu, '73; Innes and Tansy, '80; Applegate et al., '82; Iwata et al., '87; Ledoux, et al., '90b; Davis, '92) and the orbital cortex (Bailey and Sweet, '40; Delgado and Livingston, '48; Chapman et al., '49; Grantham, '51; Sterb and Smith, '55; Anand and Dua, '56; Cooper, '75; Holson, '86; Sullivan and Henke, '861, electrical stimulation can evoke behavioral responses that resemble fear, stress, anxiety, rage, arousal, defense; and pain; and ablation can alter these responses.
In animals, these types of behavior are usually accompanied by changes in heart rate, blood pressure, respiration, salivation, gagging, piloerection, and pupillary dilatation.
These autonomic and endocrine responses may be evoked by activation of peripheral receptors in somatic, visceral, gustatory, olfactory, visual, and auditory systems.
Amygdaloid and orbitocortical neurons are known to respond to stimulation of all these different sensory modalities.

For example, noxious mechanical (pinch) and thermal (5 and 50°C) stimuli applied to the skin, or electrical shock of tooth pulp changes the firing rate of neurons in the central nucleus of the amygdala (Machne and Segundo, '56; Azuma et al., '84; Bernard et al., '90, '92).

Similarly, noxious mechanical (pinch of the skin) and thermal (40-60°C) stimuli, immersion of a limb in ice-cold water, or distension of the gall bladder modify the activity of neurons in the ventrolateral orbital cortex (El-Yassir and Dostrovsky, '90; Backonja and Miletic, '91; Snow et al., '92).

Innocuous thermal stimuli (Azuma et al., '84; Bernard et al., '90) or light mechanical contact with the surface of the body (Machne and Segundo, '56; Sawa and Delgado, '63; Ben-Ari et al., '74; Azuma et al., '84; Bernard et al., '901, as well as stretching a muscle (Machne and Segundo, '56) affect the activity of neurons in the anterior, basal, lateral, and central nuclei of the amygdala.

Electrical stimulation of visceral nerves including the carotid sinus, aortic depressor and vagus, or chemical activation of baroand chemoreceptors induces a response in basal and central amygdaloid nuclei neurons that are thought to play a role in circulatory and cardiovascular control (Machne and Segundo, '56; Radna and MacLean, '81; Cechetto and Calaresu, '83a, '84, '85).

In addition, basic gustatory (taste of sucrose, saline, acids, and quinine) and olfactory (scent of food, salt, and tobacco) stimuli produce changes in the activity of amygdaloid neurons implicated with feeding and sexual behavior (Machne and Segundo, '56; Sawa and Delgado, '63; O'Keefe and Bouma, '69; Ben-Ari et al., '74; Schwartzbaum and Morse, '78; Azuma et al., '84).

Finally, simple (flash of light or auditory clicks) and complex (presentation of live animals or imitation of other animals) visual and auditory stimuli alter the firing of amygdaloid neurons that may subserve learning and conditioning (Machne and Segundo, '56; Creutzfeldt et al., '63; Sawa and Delgado, '63; O'Keefe and Bouma, '69; Ben-Ari et al., '74; Sanghera et al., '79; Pascoe and Kapp, '85; Bernard et al., '90).
A general conclusion from the response properties of neurons in the amygdala and orbital cortex, then, must be that these regions receive information from many sensory modalities.
Of particular interest to us is the way in which sensory information originating from cutaneous and visceral structures reaches the amygdala and orbital cortex.

Since the amygdala is located in the temporal lobe and the orbital cortex in the frontal lobe, both believed to be removed from major direct spinal ascending sensory pathways described previously, it has been generally believed that sensory spinal cord neurons ascend to these regions mainly via multisynaptic pathways in the brainstem, thalamus, and cortex (reviewed by Turner and Herkenham, '91).

This notion has been widely supported by a large number of studies demonstrating the involvement of the parabrachial nucleus (Norgen, '76; Zemlan et al., '78; Saper and Loewy, '80; Cechetto and Calaresu, '83b, '85; Cechetto, et al., '85; Ma and Peschanski, '88; Bernard et al., '89, '90; Blomqvist et al., '89; Ma et al., '89; Hylden et al., '89; Bernard and Besson, 'go), the nucleus tractus solitarius (Torvik, '56; Miura and Reis, '72; Loewy and Burton, '78; Ricardo and Koh, '78; Ciriello and Calaresu, '81; Otterson, '81; Hamilton and Norgen, '84; Menetrey and Basbaum, '87; Person, '89), the reticular formation (Otterson, '811, the central gray (Otterson, '81) and the thalamic medial geniculate nucleus (LeDoux et al., '85, '87, '90a) in processing and relaying visceral, tactile and nociceptive information to the amygdala.

Somatosensory and nociceptive information was shown to reach the ventrolateral orbital cortex through a relay in the nucleus submedius (Craig and Burton, '81; Dostrovsky and Guilbaud, '88; Ma et al., '88; Miletic and Coffield, '89; Yoshida et al., '92), a thalamic area that receives projections from the spinal cord and trigeminal nucleus caudalis (Craig and Burton, '81; Peschenski, '84; Dado and Giesler, '90; Yoshida et al., '91).
Recently, however, two anatomical studies provided evidence for an additional, direct projection of spinal cord neurons to the amygdala and orbital cortex.

In the first, Cliffer et al. ('91) demonstrated that injections of the anterograde tracer Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) in the spinal cord labeled axons in the central nucleus of the amygdala and in the medial orbital cortex.

In the second, Menetrey and de Pommery ('91) reported that injections of the retrograde tracer protein-gold complex in the central nucleus of the amygdala labeled neurons in lower thoracic and lumbosacral segments of the spinal cord.

In the present study, we attempted to quantitatively determine as precisely as possible the laminar and segmental distribution of neurons in all levels of the spinal cord that project directly to all regions of the amygdala and orbital cortex by: (1) using a retrograde tracer, Fluoro-Gold (FG), which has been found to be highly effective in labeling projecting neurons in the rat (Schmued and Fallon, '86; Burstein et al., '90a); (2) filling all amygdala and orbital cortex regions that have been shown to contain neurons responsive to somatosensory stimulation or to receive direct input from the spinal cord; (3) quantitatively examining the laminar distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons at all levels of the spinal cord; and (4) controlling for nonspecific labeling by injecting regions dorsolateral and medial to the amygdala.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Male Sprague-Dawley rats (300-550 g) were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (50 mgikg) and placed in a stereotaxic frame.
Atropine was administered intraperitoneally (1 mgikg).
Pressure injections were made with a glass micropipette (tip diameter = 15-25 pm) attached to a 5 p1 Hamilton microsyringe.

Fluoro-Gold was used as the retrograde tracer in this study because of its effectiveness in labeling spinal cord neurons that project to the diencephalon (Burstein et al., '90a,b), its ability to label both cell bodies and proximal dendrites (Schmued and Fallon, '86), and its ability to remain confined within neurons following a long survival time (Schmued and Fallon, '86).
A 4% solution of FG was injected into either the amygdala (12 rats) or the orbital cortex (5 rats).

Attempts were made to fill all amygdaloid nuclei that were found to contain neurons responsive to somatosensory stimuli (e.g., central, anterior, basal and lateral nuclei) or to receive direct input from the spinal cord (e.g., central nucleus).
Since the amygdala extends over 3,500 ym rostrocaudally, small injections (100 nl each) were made at two anterior-posterior planes separated by 1,000 ym.
Micropipettes were inserted into the amygdala on the right side at an angle of 36" from vertical by using a temporal approach.
This angled penetration into the brain prevented the spread of FG into the optic tract, internal capsule, hypothalamus, or thalamus.
Because of the temporal approach to the amygdala, FG was also found in the parietal cortex and lateral area of caudateputamen.
In control studies, similar injections (100 nl) were centered in these regions, dorsal and lateral to the amygdala.

In the orbital cortex, attempts were made to inject FG into nuclei that were found to receive direct spinal projections (e.g., medial orbital) or to contain neurons responsive to somatosensory stimulation (e.g., ventrolateral orbital).
In order to fill this region of the orbital cortex, six injections (50 nl each) were made in each animal.

Stereotaxic penetrations for injections of FG were made at one rostrocaudal plane (5.2 mm anterior to Bregma), three mediolateral locations (0.7, 1.2, and 2.0 mm lateral to the midline), and two dorsoventral points (2.0 and 2.5 mrn below cortical surface).
All cases in which injections of FG were restricted to the intended areas were further processed.

The effectiveness of the amygdaloid injections was evaluated by examining the parabrachial nuclei, the periaqueductal gray, the raphe nuclei, and the nucleus of the solitary tract for FG-labeled neurons.
These nuclei are known to project to the amygdala (Ricardo and Koh, '78; Saper and Loewy, '80; Otterson, '81; Cechetto et al., '83; Bernard et al., '89).
To evaluate the effectiveness and spread of orbitocortical injections, the thalamus was examined for retrogradely labeled neurons.

Thalamic neurons in the submedius and dorsomedial nuclei are known to project to the ventral, lateral and ventrolateral regions of the orbital cortex (Krettek and Price, '77; Coffield et al., '92; Yoshida et al., '92).
Analysis of results was based on the five cases with the most labeled neurons in the spinal cord.

Five to seven days following tracer injections, rats were anesthetized, flushed with physiological saline, and perfused with a 4% paraformaldehyde solution at low pH (6.5) followed by a 4% paraformaldehyde solution in high pH (9.2) (Berod et al., '81).
After perfusion, the brain and identified spinal cord segments were removed and postfixed (in the high pH fixative) for at least 12 hours.
The tissue was then stored overnight in 20% sucrose in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) at 4°C.
Brain and spinal cord sections were cut transversely on a freezing microtome at 100 and 40 pm, respectively, mounted serially on gelatin-coated slides and coverslipped with DPX.
Injection sites were initially reconstructed using the combination of darkfield and reflected ultraviolet illumination microscopy.

To better identify the location and boundaries of nuclei within the amygdala or orbital cortex, alternate sections of injection sites were counterstained with Neutral Red and examined under brightfield illumination.

The cytoarchitectonic structure and divisions of the amygdala were identified from the detailed description of Krettek and Price ('78) or Turner and Zimmer ('841, and mapped according to the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86).
Divisions within the orbital cortex were also recognized from the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86) and from Krettek and Price ('77).
Retrogradely labeled neurons in the spinal cord were observed through a microscope equipped with epi-fluorescent illumination, and mapped through a camera lucida drawing attachment.
In all cases, labeled neurons were counted from every other section of 18 spinal cord segments: C1-2, C4-5, C7-8, T4,T6, T8, T12, L1-6, and S1-2.

In order to analyze rostrocaudal distribution of labeled neurons in the spinal cord, segments were grouped into upper cervical (C1-2), lower cervical ((24-5 and 7-81, thoracic (T4,6, 8 and 12), lumbar (Ll-51, or sacral (L6-S2) (Burstein et al., '90a).

Locations of labeled neurons were described according to the nomenclature of Burstein et al. ('90a): superficial dorsal horn (SDH); deep dorsal horn (DDH) including the lateral reticulated area (LRA); area around the central canal (ACCI; intermediate zonelventral horn (IZIVH); and lateral spinal nucleus (LSN).

Results.S: Injections of FG into the amygdala

TTE.S: In nine cases, injections of FG into the amygdala did not spread to the thalamus, hypothalamus, internal capsule, supraoptic decussation, optic tract, diagonal band of Broca, bed nucleus of stria terminalis, nucleus accumbens, or septa1 nuclei.
An attempt was made to fill the central amygdaloid nucleus since spinal cord neurons were found to send axons directly into this region (Cliffer et al., '91).
To verify that FG injections spread to the central nucleus of the amygdala, the nucleus of the solitary tract was examined for retrogradely labeled neurons.
In all cases, FGlabeled neurons were found in the nucleus of the solitary tract.
The spread of FG following injections into the amygdala is described in Table 1 for the five cases with the most labeled neurons in the spinal cord.
In these cases, 330,284,263,172, and 104 neurons were counted in the 18 examined spinal cord segments of Amyg 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively.
In the other four cases, large injections that virtually filled the amygdala labeled only small number of neurons (40-80) in the spinal cord.
Based on the poor labeling in the spinal cord, these cases were not analyzed further.

Since most pressure injections of FG result in tissue damage (Dado et al., 'go), we have used local necrosis to indicate the center of each injection (++) and the extracellular FG halo to denote regions of tracer spread (+ 1.
Photomicrographs of the center of three injections of FG into the amygdala (Amyg 1, 2, and 3) are shown in Figure 1A-C.
Reconstructions of the areas containing the injections of FG in the amygdala are illustrated in Figure 2.
In three cases, FG injections spread 95, 150, and 300 pm into the ventrolateral part of the internal capsule.
In all of these cases, there was an increase in the number of labeled neurons found in the spinal cord (429, 573, and 654 cells, respectively).
Some of these retrogradely labeled neurons were located within gray matter regions where very few cells were labeled following injections restricted to the amygdala.

For example, in the three cases where FG spread to the internal capsule, the superficial dorsal horn contained 70 labeled neurons (an average of 23.3 cells per animal) while in the nine cases where FG was restricted to the amygdala, a total of 13 neurons (an average of 1.4 cells per animal) were retrogradely labeled in this region.
Thus, it is possible that the FG that spread to the internal capsule labeled spinal cord neurons that project to the hypothalamus through this region (Burstein et al., '91; Cliffer et al., '91).
Therefore, cases in which FG spread to the internal capsule were not included in this study.
Neurons labeled by injections of FG into the amygdala
Following injections of FG into the amygdala, retrogradely labeled neurons were found bilaterally in all examined segments of the spinal cord.
Figure 1 shows photomicrographs of FG-labeled neurons in the various levels of the spinal cord.
Reconstructions of the injections of FG and the locations of the retrogradely labeled neurons in Amyg 1 are depicted in Figure 2.
In our best case, 3 30 labeled neurons were found in alternate sections of the 18 examined spinal segments.
For this case (Amyg I), the numbers of spinoamygdaloid tract neurons counted in each region of the spinal gray matter and in each segment are given in Table 2.

The histograms in Figure 3 illustrate the means (n = 5) of the percentages of FG-labeled neurons found in each region of the spinal gray matter throughout the length of the spinal cord (Fig. 3A), and in each segmental group (Fig. 3B).
Following injections of FG into the amygdala, retrogradely labeled neurons were found in several regions of the spinal gray matter (Figs. 1, 2 and Table 2).
Approximately half (51 5 lo%, mean 2 S.D.) of the labeled neurons were found in the deep dorsal horn (Fig. 3A).
Most of these neurons were located in the dorsal half of the lateral reticulated area in cervical segments, and near the ventral half in lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments.
Photomicrographs show labeled neurons in the lateral reticulated area (Fig. lF-H,J) and just ventral to it within the deep dorsal horn (Fig. lK,N).
The area around the central canal contained on average 13 +1.5% of the labeled neurons (Fig. 3A).
The majority (approximately 60%) of labeled neurons around the central canal were located in the upper lumbar segments (Table 2).
The intermediate zone/ventral horn contained approximately 10% (9.4 -+ 2.0%) of the labeled neurons (Fig. 3A).
Within this region, most neurons were found in upper cervical and lumbar segments.
Only few spinoamygdaloid neurons were found in this area at lower cervical, thoracic and sacral segments.
A labeled neuron in the intermediate zone is illustrated in Figure 1K.
The lateral spinal nucleus contained 25 t 10% of the total number of labeled neurons found in the spinal cord UC LC T L S
following the injections into the amygdala (Fig. 3A).
In this region,FG-labeled neurons were evenly distributed throughout the length of the spinal cord.
Each spinal segment contained about 2-3 neurons within the LSN on each side.
A photomicrograph of FG-labeled neurons in the dorsal half of the lateral funiculus is presented in Figure 11.
The superficial dorsal horn contained almost no ( < 19%) labeled neurons at any of the examined spinal cord segments (Fig. 3A).
The number of labeled neurons in this region was largest (6 cells) in the case of the injection with the greatest spread into the globus pallidus ventrallis (Table 1).
The distribution of labeled neurons throughout the length of the spinal cord was similar for each of the 5 cases analyzed (Amyg 1-5).
The percentages of labeled neurons found in each segmental group are shown in Figure 3B.
Photomicrographs of FG-labeled neurons in cervical (Fig.1F-I), thoracic (Fig. lJ), and lumbar (Fig. 1K-0) segments are shown.

Results.S: In general, almost half (49.2 i 5.4%) of the neurons in the spinal cord that project to the amygdala originate from the upper cervical (C1-2,24.6 ?10.5%) and the upper lumbar (L1-3,24.6 2 4.1%) segments.
The lower cervical (C4-5 and 7-8) and all 4 thoracic (T4,6, 8 and 12) segments contain about 18% of the labeled neurons (18 _t 2.2 and 18 +1.4%, respectively).
Lower lumbar segments (L4-5) contained 8.7 & 1.5%, and the segments caudal to it (L6-S2) 7.7 2 1.5%.
In all cases (Amyg 1-51, FG injections were unilateral, restricted to the right side.
Following unilateral amygdaloid injections, 60.4 r 4.9% of the labeled neurons were found in the contralateral spinal cord.
Within the DDH, ACC and IZIVH, more neurons were located contralateral to the injected side (68%, 615% and 65%, respectively).
In the LSN, labeled neurons were evenly distributed (47% contralateral, 53% ipsilateral) on both sides.
Along the length of the spinal cord, more neurons were located contralateral to the injected side within lower cervical, thoracic, and lumbar segments (67%, 66%, and 66%/, respectively).
However, the percentages of contralaterally located neurons in the upper cervical and sacral segments were lower (47% and 52%,, respectively).
In all cases, injections of FG into the amygdala spread to the parietal cortex and the lateral region of the caudal end of caudate-putamen (Table 1 and Fig. 2).
This spread raises the possibility that some retrogradely labeled neurons in the spinal cord were neurons that project to the parietal cortex or lateral caudate-putamen but not to the amygdala.

TTE.S: To test this possibility, FG was injected exclusively into the same regions in the parietal cortex and lateral caudateputamen that were found to contain FG following the amygdaloid injections (Table 1 ).
Reconstructions of a control injection that resulted in the greatest number of labeled neurons (44 cells) in the spinal cord are illustrated in Figure 4.
These neurons were found mainly in the deep dorsal horn and the lateral spinal nucleus.

Results.S: Injections of FG into the orbital cortex

TTE.S: In five cases, injections of FG into the orbital cortex did not spread caudally or ventrally into the globus pallidus, nucleus accumbens, nucleus of the diagonal band of Broca, septa1 nuclei, or any other telencephalic region known to receive direct projections from the spinal cord.
An attempt was made to fill the medial and ventral region of the orbital cortex since it was found to contain PHA-L-labeled axons of spinal origin (Cliffer et al., '91).
The spread of FG in the various areas of the orbital cortex and in neighboring cortical regions following injections into the orbital cortex is described in Table 3.
In all cases, FG spread caudally to the anterior portion of the ventrolateral orbital nucleus.
Photomicrographs of the center of three injections of FG into the orbital cortex (OC-3, 1 and 2) are shown in Figure 5A-C.
Reconstructions of the areas containing the center of the five (OC 1-5) injections of FG into the orbital cortex are illustrated in Figure 6.
In these cases, 70,61,44,33, and 31 labeled neurons were counted in the 18 examined spinal cord segments of OC 1-5, respectively (Table 3).
To verify that FG injections spread to regions in the orbital cortex that receive thalamic input, the thalamus was examined for retrogradely labeled neurons.
In all cases, FG-labeled neurons were found in the thalamic nucleus submedius, dorsomedial, ventrolateral, ventromedial, rhomboid and reuniens, ipsilateral to the injection site.

The presence of labeled neurons in these nuclei suggests that the ventral, lateral, and ventrolateral regions of the orbital cortex were included in the injection (Krettek and Price, '77; Coffield et al., '92; Yoshida et al., '92).
Neurons labeled by injections of FG into the orbital cortex
Following injections of FG into the orbital cortex, a small number of retrogradely labeled neurons was consistently found throughout the length of the spinal cord.
Figure 5 illustrates retrogradely labeled neurons in cervical, thoracic, and lumbar segments.
Reconstructions of the locations of the FG-labeled neurons found in the spinal cord of all five cases (OC 1-5) are shown in Figure 6.
In the 18 examined segments, 239 labeled neurons were counted in alternate sections (Fig. 6).
The histograms in Figure 7 illustrate the means (n = 5) of the percentages of FGlabeled neurons counted in the various regions of the gray matter (Fig. 7A), and in each segmental group (Fig. 7B).
Figure 8 illustrates the rostrocaudal spread of FG in the orbital cortex and the labeling it produced in the spinal cord of a single case.
For this case (OCl), the numbers of spinoorbitocortical tract neurons counted in each region of the spinal gray matter and in each segment are given in Table 4.
Following injections of FG into the orbital cortex, the majority (62 2 11%) of labeled neurons in the spinal cord were found in the lateral reticulated area and the deep dorsal horn (Fig. 7A).
In cervical segments, neurons were primarily located in the lateral reticulated area.
In contrast, in thoracic and lumbar segments, these neurons were located just ventral to, or within the ventromedial region of the lateral reticulated area.
Photomicrographs of FGlabeled neurons in the lateral reticulated area (Fig. 5D-G and I) and deep dorsal horn (Fig. 5H, J and K-M) are shown.

Following all injections of FG into the orbital cortex, only a few labeled neurons were found in the gray matter surrounding the central canal (10.4 2 6.5%), in the intermediate zone/ventral horn (12.6 2 10%) or in the lateral spinal nucleus (15.2 t 10.7%).
Labeled neurons in the ACC and IZiVH were found in upper cervical (Cl-21, lower thoracic and upper lumbar (T12-L3) segments.
Figure 1N and 1K illustrates FG-labeled neurons in the area around the central canal and in the lateral spinal nucleus, respectively.
Throughout the length of the spinal cord, retrogradely labeled neurons were evenly distributed in upper cervical (18.6 2 6%), lower cervical (16 t 6.5%) and thoracic (18 t 1.4%) segments.
Almost half (47 2 11%) of the labeled neurons were found in the lumbar cord.
Of these, the majority were located within the first and second lumbar segments.
The distribution of labeled neurons in each segmental group is shown in Figure 7B.
Photomicrographs of labeled neurons in the upper cervical (Fig. 5D), lower cervical (Fig. 5E,F), thoracic (Fig. 5G-I, and K), and lumbar (Fig. 55 and L-N) segments are illustrated.
In all cases, injections of FG were restricted to one side of the orbital cortex.
Following these injections, 73% t 9.0 of the labeled neurons in the spinal cord were found contralatera1 to the injection site.
Within the various areas of the gray matter 76%,85%, 76%, and 41% of the labeled neurons were found in the contralateral DDH, IZIVH, ACC, and LSN, respectively.
In the different segmental groups, 41%, 81%, 86%, and 77% of the neurons were counted in the contralateral UC, LC, T, and L, respectively.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Technical considerations

The present study extends previous observations of direct spinal projections to the amygdala and orbital cortex in the rat by describing the locations of spinal cord neurons at the origin of these pathways through the use of the retrograde tracer FG.
At present, direct projections from the spinal cord to the telencephalon and cortex are only documented in the rat and thus, the discussion is limited to findings in this species.
Fluoro-Gold (hydroxystilbamidine) is a fluorescent weak base that can be taken up by nerve terminals, accumulated by lysosomes and transported to the cell body by passive diffusion (Wessendorf, '91).
During the past five years, it has been widely used in neuroanatomical studies as a highly effective retrograde axonal tracer that can label somata and proximal dendrites (Schmued and Fallon, '86).
However, FG can also be transported by axons passing through, but not terminating in, the injected regions (Dado et al., '90).
It is possible, therefore, that our injections of FG in the amygdala and orbital cortex resulted in nonspecific labeling of spinal cord neurons.

We believe that such labeling has not affected our results significantly as spinal cord axons have not been found to ascend through the amygdala to more rostral or dorsal regions of the brain, and no axons of spinal origin were observed rostral to the orbital cortex.
However, if in the future spinal axons are found to cross the amygdala en route to other brain regions, or rostral to the orbital cortex, our results will have to be reinterpreted.

To control for nonspecific labeling of spinoamygdaloid tract neurons, FG was injected into the regions in the parietal cortex and lateral caudate-putamen that were found to contain the spread of injection in all cases.
The labeling in the spinal cord, although minimal, is surprising as previous studies didn't show direct spinal projection to these regions.

Although this finding must be confirmed with other anatomical and physiological techniques, it raises the possibility that about 10% of the labeling in the spinal cord may arise from projections to regions outside the amygdala.

A great concern in this study was the potential spread of FG into the supraoptic decussation and internal capsule, regions known to contain a large number of ascending spinohypothalamic tract axons (Burstein et al., '91; Cliffer et al., '91).
Such spread could have contributed to the labeling of spinal cord neurons.

However, the virtual lack of labeling in the superficial dorsal horn, an area known to contain neurons projecting to the hypothalamus (Burstein et al., 'goal, suggests that uptake of FG by spinohypothalamic tract axons did not occur.
In two cases (Amyg 1 and 21, minor spread of FG (less than 400 Fm) was found in the transition zone between the amygdala and the globus pallidus ventralis.
This region includes the ventral pallidum, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and the substantia innominata.

Since the borders between these nuclei and the central amygdaloid nucleus are unclear, and since neurons located in the central amygdaloid nucleus and in the adjacent dorsomedial region receive similar afferent input (De Olmos et al., '85; Grove, '88) and respond similarly to nociceptive stimuli (Bernard et al., '92) we included the two cases with spread to globus pallidus ventralis in the study.
The labeling in the spinal cord following amygdaloid injections that did not spread to globus pallidus ventralis was slightly smaller.
This suggests that, the spread of FG into this region did not contribute much to the labeling in the spinal cord.

Nevertheless, it should be noted that spinal cord neurons were found to project to the ventral pallidum, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and the substantia innominata (Cliffer et al., '91), and thus it is possible that some of the labeled neurons in the spinal cord project to these nuclei.
Distributions of spinal cord neurons that project to the amygdala and orbital cortex, and comparison with other spinal projections to the telencephalon
In our best case, FG injections into the amygdala labeled 330 neurons in alternate sections of the 18 examined spinal cord segments.
This number is similar to the number of spinal cord neurons that project to the septa1 nuclei and nucleus accumbens in the telencephalon (Burstein et al., '89) of the rat.
However, considering the size of the amygdala, this number is surprisingly small.
It should be noted that in an attempt to prevent the spread of FG into the internal capsule and supraoptic decussation, our injections did not completely fill the central nucleus of the amygdala.

Since this nucleus receives the densest input from the spinal cord (Cliffer et al., '91) it is possible that the number of spinal cord neurons that project directly to the amygdala is actually larger.

Nevertheless, since injections that filled the central nucleus and spread minimally to the internal capsule labeled only 100 more neurons in the spinal cord, and since in all cases FG was effectively transported from the central amygdaloid nucleus, as evident by the labeling in the nucleus of the solitary tract (see Materials andMethods), it is likely that the failure to fill the central nucleus completely did not greatly reduce the number of labeled neurons in the spinal cord.
Regarding the orbital cortex, fewer than 100 labeled neurons were counted in the examined spinal cord segments.
The paucity of labeling in the spinal cord can raise a question about the effectiveness of the injections in the orbital cortex.

The locations of retrogradely labeled neurons in the thalamus, however, suggest that the injections included, and were effective in labeling neurons that project to the ventral, lateral and ventrolateral orbital cortex.

Since the labeling of thalamic neurons with FG was similar to the labeling that was found in previous studies (Krettek and Price, '77; Coffield et al., '92; Yoshida et al., '92) in the rat, it is li$ely that the small number of labeled neurons in the spinal cord is indicative of the size of this projection rather than a technical inability to label neurons.

In no case were injections of FG restricted to areas known to receive thalamic input only (e.g., ventrolateral orbital cortex) or spinal input only (e.g., medial orbital cortex); therefore, we cannot correlate the size and spread of injections with the labeling in the spinal cord.

Within the various regions of the gray matter, most spinoamygdaloid (approximately 65%) and spino-orbitocortical (more than 70%) tract neurons were found in the lateral reticulated area (lamina V), the deep dorsal horn and the area around the central canal (lamina X).

Neurons in these laminae have been implicated in the transmission of sensory and nociceptive information as they receive input from primary afferent nociceptors (Light and Perl, '79; Sugiura et al., '861, respond to noxious stimulation (Hillman and Wall, '69; Christensen and Perl, '70; Nahin et al., '83; Coghill et al., '91), and project to the brainstem (Chaouch et al., '83; Menetrey et al., '82; Menetrey and Basbaum, '87), diencephalon (Giesler et al., '76; Kevetter and Willis, '83; Granum, '86; Kemplay and Webster, '86; Hylden et al., '89; Lima and Coimbra, '88; Craig et al., '89; Burstein et al., '90a,b; Carstens et al., '90; Menetrey and de Pommery, '91), and telencephalon (Burstein and Giesler, '89; Menetrey and de Pommery, '91).

The presence of these neurons at all levels of the spinal cord suggests that sensory and nociceptive information arising from the entire body may reach the amygdala and orbital cortex, at least in part, directly via the spinoamygdaloid and spino-orbitocortical tracts.
About 10% of the labeled neurons were located in the intermediate zone and ventral horn at C1-2 and thoracolumbar regions.

Intermediate zone neurons in the thoracolumbar region are known to receive input from visceral and cutaneous primary afferent axons (Ciriello and Calaresu, '83; Sugiura et al., '86, '89), and to respond to noxious visceral (Ness and Gebhart, '88; Menetrey et al., '89) and proprioceptive (Giesler et al., '76; Menetrey et al., '84) stimuli.
Therefore, it is possible that spinoamygdaloid and spino-orbitocortical tract neurons may also be involved in carrying noxious visceral and proprioceptive information.
Twenty-five percent of spinoamygdaloid and 15% of spino-orbitocortical tract neurons were located in the lateral spinal nucleus.

The role of this nucleus is not clear; its neurons do not respond to sensory stimulation (Giesler et al., '79, Menetrey et al., '80) and hence are unlikely to carry sensory information to the amygdala or orbital cortex.
Of special interest is the finding that neurons in the superficial dorsal horn (lamina I) of the spinal cord were not found to project directly into the amygdala or orbital cortex.

Instead, they are believed to project to the amygdala mainly through a relay in the parabrachial nucleus (Cechetto et al., '83; Blomqvist et al., '89; Bernard et al., '891, and to the orbital cortex through a relay in the thalamic nucleus submedius (Craig and Burton, '81; Dostrovsky and Guilbaud, '88; Miletic and Coffield, '89; Yoshida et al., '91).

However, at least in the rat, direct projections of lamina I neurons to the nucleus submedius are confined to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis (Dado and Giesler, 'go), and thus its role in relaying information from spinal cord lamina I neurons to the orbital cortex is unlikely.

Nevertheless, the lack of labeled neurons in lamina I distinguishes the spinoamygdaloid and the spino-orbitocortical tracts from the spinothalamic (Giesler et al., '76; Kevetter and Willis, '83; Granum, '86; Kemplay and Webster, '86; Lima and Coimbra, '88; Hylden et al., '89; Burstein et al., 'gob), spinohypothalamic (Burstein et al., '90a; Carstens et al., '90; Menetrey and de Pommery, '91), spinomesencephalic (Menetrey et al., '82; Swett et al., '85; Hylden et al., '89), spinoreticular (Chaouch et al., '831, and spinosolitary (Menetrey and Basbaum, '87) tracts in the rat.

In the lack, or paucity, of labeling in the SDH, the spinoamygdaloid and spino-orbitocortical projections resemble the projections from the spinal cord to the nucleus accumbens and septal nuclei (Burstein and Giesler, '89).

In general, the location of spinal cord neurons that project to the amygdala or orbital cortex is similar to the location of spinal cord neurons that project to the nucleus accumbens and septal nuclei.

The lateral reticulated area of all examined segments and the deep dorsal horn and intermediate zone of lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments contain the majority of neurons that project to each of these telencephalic nuclei (Burstein and Giesler, '89).
This distribution suggests preferential input to these regions from the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral dermatomes and from visceral organs in the lower abdomen, pelvis, and perineum.

As mentioned, the projections from the spinal cord to the amygdala are similar in magnitude to the projections to the septal nuclei and nucleus accumbens, while the projections to the orbital cortex are smaller.

Using the same retrograde tracer and examining the identical segments, we counted 330, 70, 430, and 273 neurons in the spinal cord following the most effective injections of FG into the amygdala, orbital cortex, nucleus accumbens, and septal nuclei (Burstein and Giesler, '891, respectively.

By comparing these numbers with the number of counted neurons in the spinal cord (4,127) following injection of FG into the hypothalamus (Burstein et al., 'goal, we calculated that the projections to areas rostra1 and lateral to the hypothalamus may constitute about 25% of the spinohypothalamic tract.
Currently, we do not know how many spinal cord neurons project to more than one target and along what pathway these neurons reach their target nuclei in the telencephalon.

If each neuron projects to only one target and its axon passes through the hypothalamus but does not terminate there, it is possible that the number of spinohypothalamic tract neurons is smaller than previously estimated.

To answer this, further studies must examine whether spinal cord neurons project to only one or to several regions in the teiencephalon, and demonstrate the actual termination of spinal cord neurons in the hypothalamus.

The results of the present study characterize pathways through which somatosensory and nociceptive information from the spinal cord might reach the amygdala and orbital cortex directly, bypassing the brainstem, thalamus and cortex.

Although minor, these projections can theoretically transmit sensory information to the amygdala and orbital cortex earlier, as they do not synapse on the way, and hence may contribute to more rapid processing of somatosensory information, including pain.
